After a Software Update:
 
1.Battery life is PATHETIC!
 
2.We cannot access our files in the Mobile via Computer, which previously had access.
 
3.Fast Charging is No more. And it takes 5 hrs to charge fully, that too if Mobile is OFF. If we ON the Mobile before charging reaches 40%, it drains very fast.
 
4.Phone becoming heat, ALL which previously wasnt there.
 
The primary purpose of using a Mobile is to Receive or Dial a Call. If that was the only purpose, then we dont have to choose something like Samsung S6, instead there are MANY cheaper Mobiles, whose Battery last more than 3 days and whose datas are not stolen by any Google or Samsung or FB or Whatsapp or any other companies/ medias.
 
We use these kind of Mobiles for using Internet & for its speed mainly. But, now a days, if the Internet is ON, within 1-hr, the Mobile Battery drains and the Mobile is gone OFF.
 
Imagine: 
 you want to use a Map to navigating to an unknown place and the Battery drains super fast and you end up in the half way 
Or even you want to watch a training video in Youtube & with in 1-hr, it is OFF  
Or you had an important call conference or video chat & the Bloody Mobile is OFF on the half way and imagine the situation after going OFF and  
Now, you wanted to Charge the mobile URGENTLY, as You expect some important calls like any verification or customer calls & the hell dont get charged! It takes half an hour to just charge INITIAL 5-10% only. If you ON the mobile during this 10%, it directly jumps to 3% and if u get into the Dialler pad re-jumps to 1%. As you click Dial button, a logo appears with Blue colour text 'SAMSUNG' with a Black Background.
 
When we purchase a product, we always evaluate its Brand Facility (like ability of accessing our files in Mobile via Computer, unlike Apple Brand), Product Facility (use of Internet, Battery life & the Mobile phone Durability as it was a High-end Phone). We believe that these facilities can be used till the end of that product. Only after satisfying these conditions, we pay our hard earned money to buy this product. 
 
A BRAND becomes a Brand when their Promisories are maintained till the end of its use. Facts being the above, one fine morning how can they change these facilities to NIL for EXISTING USERS who had paid believing these previous facilities?
 
So, forget about Samsung S6.
 
(I am a Samsung S6 user for 1 and half years and am NOT a heavy user)

Only posting this because hopefully Samsung goes through public forums such as these when looking for bugs.
 
Since the November security update the Samsung app icons have been slightly misaligned in the apps drawer (doesn't seem to be happening for Google / other apps). This misalignment also exists in widgets on the homescreen panes (weather and music - these are lower down than they should be when placed on the top of the homescreen panes). These haven't been fixed with the December security update that I recently received.
 
The widget for Samsung Music app also seems to be displaying album art with the incorrect aspect ratio (this was fixed in mid 2016 but it's back).
 
Generally though my S6 (128GB variant) is doing well. Will be interested in the Oreo update and how it goes. At this point the battery is showing its age and I'm contemplating the S7 Edge battery mod to increase the life of my S6.

So I've had the Nougat update for two weeks. Some impressions in that time: 
- I had to factory reset due to issues with Play Services (nil app issues now) 
- Overall performance seems to have decreased (I am seeing some lags in system animation, notably in the stock Gallery app) 
- Battery life is a mixed bag. My standby time has decreased (losing around 10% every 7 hours of standby), however when I am actually using the phone the battery life seems unchanged. Some additional background processes maybe? 
- Camera performance, notably low-light, seems to have gotten worse. On Marshmallow the low-light performance was actually quite good, but with Nougat there is a lot more noise. That and, the Nougat camera app shows some lags, and looks (and feels) childish with all the swiping (Marshmallow was more 'mature' in that regard).
 
Overall the update is definitely usable. That said, if I knew what I know now with the Nougat update, I would have stayed on Marshmallow. Hope that helps some people still on the fence.

Most of the time Factory Reset will rectify any problems after the upgrade.

Do check the notification on the signal bars strength and whether it indicate 4G, H+, 3G. 
If it keep switching between H+ and 3G &or missing, it mean the signal is no good. 
If it is in one location, do check with your Telecom on this location signal.
 
Other option is to go to Setting -> Mobile networks -> Access Point Names. 
Ensure the APN setting are correct or not by either contact your Telecom support or reset the APN, which may be available in the Telecom website including facebook.
 
At the same time check with your Telecom on whether they have VoLTE. 
S6 do have this feature as Voice over LTE, meaning that while you are talking on the phone and you can do surf internet at the same time. It is similar to HD voice.
 
Signal strength do use much battery power. If it is poor signal, battery would be drain faster. Normal before going out, i check the battery % and if below 50%, i put to charge using the original battery charger with fast charge. To know if it is a fast charger, there are 2 output voltage. It will able to charge 60% in 30 minutes, hence enough battery to use for the day. I do not use power bank due to the heat issue. Fast charge is better and safer.

The issue is on the "Sync".
 
First, you may need to understand how Gmail work. (as example on any webmail) 
Gmail messages are store physically in the website, Gmail server. 
When someone send you a message, your Gmail will received and store it. 
When you use computer to log in and view your messages. 
These messages are NOT download to your computer. 
Any action, such as; delete, read, send,;  these will take immediate effect. 
There is no action on the computer as it do not have &or store all these messages.
 
On mobile phone. 
When you enable, "Sync" the Gmail on the phone. 
Once there is a connection, either thru mobile data or wireless, this "sync" will auto DOWNLOAD messages (which is not available) to your mobile phone. 
If your phone is always Online, which enable mobile data &or wireless. 
Any message receive in the Gmail server will also be download to your phone.
 
Incoming message --->>> Gmail server --->>> mobile phone "Online".
 
Conclusion. 
Computer do not save any messages as any action is active &or live. 
Any changes made will be reflect in the Gmail server of your account.
 
But in the mobile phone, whenever any message arrived, it will be saved in your phone. 
It is not 2-ways, but only ONE way, that is to download messages not available on your phone. 
So, by enable "SYNC" and if the connection is ONLINE, messages arrived in Gmail server will be send and download to your phone.
 
But if you do not "sync" your Gmail account. 
So, when you at this moment to sync your Gmail account, your messages will then be download to the phone. 
If you had made some deletion in the computer earlier, you will not have those messages that were deleted in the phone.
 
The ANSWER to your solution is to turn OFF the "sync" on the mobile phone for Gmail.
 
Btw, any messages deleted will be found in the Trash folder of the Gmail. 
Only spam messages will be deleted from the Gmail server.
 
Hope this will clarify on your current problem.

Quote 
"RAM is nothing to do with memory" 
RAM = Random-access MEMORY. 
============================ 
Correction: 
Both are the same. 
This memory is consider as running the apps. 
If it is less than 1GB RAM, some apps may run slowly. 
Let me explained simply for you to understand. 
Open an app, a game app, and play.  
Then you press the HOME key, this app will be in the background. 
Open this app and you will see the screen where you had last played. 
Turn off the phone, and then turn on. 
Open that game app, and it will show you where you had last played. 
By right, you would say the game will have to start from the beginning, but is not.
 
Android system have made several changes, as far as i had noticed before. 
In the past when you turn off the phone, all the open apps will be closed. 
BUT a couple of years ago, the Android make a BIG change. 
When turning off the phone, it will not close any apps which is still open. 
That is why if you turn on the phone, the game app will be at the same screen you last used, before turning off. 
As what i normally do, i press the "Recent" key and clear all the apps from the background.
 
This is somewhat similar to computer term, it is call "Hibernate".
 
You may misled on another term. 
""ROM - read-only memory"" 
ROM store the Android system, as similar to computer BIOS.

	Â Flashlight torch shortcut from quick toggle settings | despite that part of the user interface was messed up on NatureUX 5 and fixed with NatureUX 6, a flashlight shortcut was something iOS 7 had in it's new control center, which could be called by sliding up from the bottom of the screen. The flashlight could be altered even while the camera is running, while that was not possible on iOS. For the S6 (and S7 with Marshmallow pre-installed), the torch shortcut will be blocked while the camera is running. This makes it impossible to alter the flashlight for burst shots and DURlNG video recording. Actually, Sony's HOMANi camera user interface offers the torch setting during video recording. HTC also can do that. 
 
Take an example from the Sony HandyCam FDR-AX33p (or AXP33), where some camera settings can be adjusted during video recording. Some settings such as resolution, framerate and bitrate can not be altered during video recording. It would be good, if it could be adjusted during video recording, but apply automatically for the next time, and the ability to discard those changes before the video recording has ended. 
Since Android Marshmallow for Samsung phones (the HTC One M9 also had that for Lollipop, like Nokia 108 and Samsung Omnia i8000 too): the pause/record button could be pressed without any delay. You could press it as many times as you can press the iPhone's shutter key (only if exposure time is short enough) per second, and it would also react. 
The Galaxy S7 also could preserve close to zero shutter lag. But as far as I know, to achieve that, the camera application needs to be excluded from all power saving procedures. The camera application should not be affected by power saving anyways, and only supported MultiWindow on the Note 4, where that glorious legacy mulWin tray was available, which had many advantages over the new system since S6. But since Android Marshmallow on S6, pressing the multi window icon on the recnet task switcher (fortunately no longer limited to 14/16 applications, but since Marshmellow affected by the rotation of the background app, which can actually be locked by tapping and holding the screen), does not cause that application to be added to the running application, but a completely new multi window session will be started. 
Additionally, the Galaxy S7 will disable zero shutter lag, if the battery temperature thereshold (probably 25 degrees of celsius.).

My experience with Galaxy S6 battery drainage: When I started to use this phone I got 1,5 days of battery live with 3,5 - 4 hrs of SOT (I don't play games, just surfing, texting, calls, youtube). Updated it to 6.01. and it worked great. 2 weeks ago I noticed that my battery performance started to drop. Battery usage over night (mobile data on) went from 5% to 20%! and for no reason. No new apps installed or anything else. Then I noticed that "Android OS"  started to use also more juice than before - from 6% it started using 30%! 10 days after this battery drainage started I changed my network provider and used another SIM card. Immediately after I changed my SIM battery drainage went to normal, just as it was in the beginning. I have no idea how changing the SIM returned my battery usage to normal, but it did. So I just wanted to share my experience, perhaps it can help someone.

Nothing else than the Samsung-logo-label itself? On phones with removable battery, some important information is usually printed inside of the battery placeholder, which you can read by opening the back covver and remove the battery. On phones with a battery, which is not considered as user-replaceable (the battery of the S6 can actually be replaced, but one doing that risks losing the warrenty), it should be printed on the back cover. Due to some rule-changes, some manufacturers cease to do that (   ), just to achieve CLEANER designs, but nobody actually even notices those symbols. They could contain some information, that could be interesing. And the model number (S6: G920F) should also be printed there. And the boot screen, which has been uglified since the S5 with every new generation, shows that Android-Logo (Âpowered by Google Android technologyÂ or something similar) since S5 (I actually like that), but no longer the model number (G900F or G901F? I am so curious‼) I know, I can look that up in the settings, but is there any reason for removing it? Cleaner boot screen? You just look at it for three seconds. Is a rookie confused by those numbers? Just ignore them!
 
I am glad, that many manufacturers still use dark boot screens. Every iPhone since iOS 7 (except iPhone 5c) uses a white background with a dark Apple as a boot screen. What's wrong with that? THe skeuomorphistic white Apple on a dark background looked more beautiful, glowed in the dark instead of looking like a creepy shadow, and if the left power in the battery is close to zero (but maybe 5 % reserve power to protect the battery itself), the white backgound could weaken the battery and cause the device to shut off instantly, like cutting off power. THis is, what usually happens with phones, that have a miscalibrated battery. Additionally, booting the phone in dark places with this white background hurts everybody's eyes as much as the camera shutter effect, which blacks out the camera viewfinder for the fraction of a seccond can be for epileptic people. Epilepsy is described on Wikipedia, if somebody does not know, what it is. There is not even a model number or a label (name of the phone, e.g. iPhone 6s) on that bootscreen.  
Random fact: I think, I once saw a phone by Sharp or Panasonic or maybe Acatel, where custom text could be added to it. But I do not know, which device it was.

Hello. TechLord/CaptainTech here.
 
I just wanted to mention, how much I always hated, when the manufcturers mentioned Âslim designÂ as an advantage of the phone. I actually never noticed the design of the phone before the GT-i8000 was negatively rated on Chip.DE due to thickness and plastic. I initially thought, they might mention it due to the envoirnment damage caused by the production and trashing of plastic. But no, later I found out, that they mentioned it, because plastic is not considered as ÂpremiumÂ. So what is the practical advantage of that? How useful is a premium and thin design, if you are in killerJo's creepy dark night wood and your thin battery is running out? Not more than a dummy phone. Even the NoPhone is more useful then, due to it's robustity. The noPhone is even waterproof! And it's non-existant camera is placed in the conrer.
 
The practical part of design is robustity (LG V10 and some other rugged outdoor phones such as Carterpillers are very shock/bump/scratch/fire/temperature/etc.-resista­nt.), comfortability (the premium-polycarbonate of the S5,Alpha,Note 3 and Note 4 felt comfortable), heat exhaustion (cooling down device: One M9 can be used to cook eggs), grip (not slide out of hand), wireless radio signals (metal might interfere with the signal strength of the wireless antenna),and waterproofity (Hyun Yeul Liar's Âdesign with purposeÂ on Unpacked2015 Episode 1 was a lie. The purpose on the S7 is stronger water-resistance. BUt not on the S6.) 
The K-Zoom and S4-Zoom have a design, which counts as a feature. 
The iPhone 4/4s's metal frame was a part of the antenna system. No bad idea, but touching it disturbed it. 
Some other practical design features are:  
	Â Physical Shutter Button (allows real camera shooting feeling, volume keys can be reserved for video recording, and applications such as games could use it.) 
	Â Camera placed in the corner (allows penetrating into every corner, holding a better and more comfortable camera grip without covering the lens, and makes it very unlikely to accidentally touch the lens in everyday use in landscape (horizontal) usage. That camera corner is the Âlonely cornerÂ, which is isolated. THe purpose of a camera is not being a part of the design language (Samsung!), and no symmetry, but being practical. You do never have to worry about accidentally covering the lens when placing into the corner. Additionally, you can estimate the position of the camrea lens on the other side of the casing very accurately. On the S7 and Nokia Lumia 920, it is positioned in the cneter vertical axis. It is not nearly as easy to estimate, where exactly the position of the camera on the other side is. And if you want to shoot and record very unobtrusively, (e.g. capture the writing board at school, if you were unable to copy it to your excercise book), you only have to hold less than a fifth of the phone casing above the school table. When the camera is placed in the middle, you have to hold at least half the phone above the table to capture something. The camera really interferes with the usage. More information is mentioned here:   Â some old Samsung devices such as the S1-i9000 and especially the Omnia ll-GT-i8000 have designs, that are focussed more on practicallity. The i8000 has a horizontal Samsung logo, which looks more professional, and the position of the camera and the flash could be the camera and the Heart/UV(N4)/SpO²-Scanner with Samsung's new design language (since S6, but not Galaxy Alpha, where it is placed on the other side of the camera.)

  
Contributes to slim design? Water-resistance is a reason. But slim design? Who had a problem with the 12mm-thick iPhone 2G? 
Take this:    
 
If I see advertisements, showing off the thin design as a feature, I know, that the manufacturer probably sacrificed features such as a practical hardware capability to achieve that. They should push the thin design to the last priority, because it might feel more premium, but a thicker phone sits better in the hand and gives me the proudness of not caring about slim design. Everybody, who sees me with a 16-Millimetres-thick phone will think: he is a person, who takes care about practicallity. This is, what I would like to be honored for.

This S6 is dual band, meaning, using 2.4GHz and 5GHz. 
Suggestion: 
Do click on both and click "Forget" to remove. 
After both SSID is removed then next. 
Turn On the wifi, and select the SSID for 2.4GHz band, log in and connected. 
Next, go to select your 5GHz SSID and log in and connected. 
Once connected, both band will be saved on the phone wifi itself.
 
My idea is to have the 5GHz SSID to be active once i turn on the wifi. 
If the 5GHz is lost, it will auto select the 2.4GHz band. 
As using 5GHz SSID, the signal strength is stronger than 2.4GHz. 
In this way, if the phone wifi lost the 5GHz signal, it will then detect the next SSID which is the 2.4GHz band. 
This work for me very good. 
Do take note that to set to the SSID, as describe above, do let the phone be close to the router to detect and connected. 
This will registered the phone for easy detect and connected to the stronger signal. 
Work for me, but up to you.

Now I understand why they say, "Once you go Mac..." 
After having the S6 for 7 months, when the manufacturer's warranty was still active, the phone's screen started turning colors when plugged into my computer, and, over the course of a couple of hours, stopped working. "Have you ever dealt with Samsung?" someone asked as I mentioned that I'd have to send in my phone for repairs. I had kept the phone in a $50 waterproof case and been careful with it, since I had previously endured the embarrassment of a cracked iPhone screen for over a year. Yet, after I sent it to in, Samsung claimed the phone wouldn't turn on due to damage to the LCD "beneath the screen"; i.e., even though the screen looked immaculate, it was broken, and they determined it was my fault. They tried to charge me more than $160 to replace the LCD screen, after which they said they couldn't be sure I wouldn't have more charges after they were able to turn on the phone.  
Contrast this experience with the time I actually *did* drop my iPhone 4S and horribly cracked the screen; yet, it still worked. After covering it with a screen protector, it worked perfectly for more than a year when I bought the S6.  
I decided to start using my 4S until I bought an iPhone 5S off of Craigslist. (Be careful with Craigslist purchases; make sure the seller will meet you in a phone store where they can check that it wasn't stolen.) My 5S works great. Again, now I understand why people say, "Once you go Mac..." This unfortunate experience confirmed for me what so many people have been telling me for years: Apple products just seem more durable.

It is counter intuitive, but the reason that the hone dims in low light and brightens in higher light is that instead of the surrounding light lighting up your screens display (like one would think), the screen of your phone actually reflects the light causing it to act like a mirror and sending the surrounding light back at you. To compensate for this increase of light being sent at you, your phone will make the display brighter. in low light settings, it doesn't need to be as bright via the same logic. Also in low light areas our eyes become accustomed to the low light and bright light tends to irritate our eyes. this is the other reason it is dimmed in low light settings.

The original charger is "Fast charge" enable. 
So it will charge to about 40% to 50% within half hour. 
DO NOT LEAVE YOUR PHONE CHARGING TOO LONG. 
Once you exceed certain hours, it will auto dis-charge the phone. 
This is to prevent damage to the phone and battery. 
Lastly, you can do charge at any time, and not necessary to wait till the phone tell you to charge. Too often will cause the battery to drain. Try do charge when below 50%. 
Once in a while, just do a full charge to 100%. 
You can stop charging at any time and any %.

Go to call (phone), and key in this character    *#0*# 
Upon the last hex input, it will show several box with word, such as Red, blue, etc 
Upon click on Red, the screen will show the color RED. 
In this way, you can identify which color tone is no good. 
To exit, you need to click twice on the back button.

Been using Samsung Galaxy S6 since this year Feb, a really nice device as a whole.
 
Performance: 
It's really a beast as  compared to last year's flagship, even till date it's still performing pretty well, fast and no lags. Handles everything really well
 
Battery: 
The only down side I have with this phone is the battery life. 
I will have to charge it at least 3-4 times when I'm at home, mainly because I use my device on a regular basis, ranging from Carousell, Instagram, Gaming and music etc.  
But not much of an issue since it has Adaptive Fast Charging, the speed is decently good. 
When I'm out, all i need is my Xiaomi 30000mAh power bank, for every charge I'll charge it to 70-85%, and I do not have to be afraid of my S6 battery going flat.
 
Storage:  
My S6 is the 32GB, which is enough for my day to day usage. 10++GB  
The system takes up about 6GB out of the 32GB 
And the apps I download only takes up 6+GB on my phone 
My main storage is mainly my videos as i like to download and watch videos on my phone, then I'll delete it after watching so it won't be taking up my phone memory
 
Camera:  
One of the best you can find in the market, when compared to 2015 flagships. No doubt about that.  
Focus is fast, image quality is great. 
 
Overall:  
I'm pleased with the performance and design of the S6, initially I was thinking of switching to iphone 6 as I was thinking of trying out iOS, but for now I'm going to stick to my S6 as I feel I can have more freedom and I can do more things with my device. I don't feel restricted when using android as it gives the end user a lot of free play as to how you want to customize it and apps are so accessible with android.  
And I think it's still a good choice to go for S6 even in 2016, if you're on a tight budget.

So after 3 months of using the phone, I will write down my review. 
Before the Android 6.0.1 the phone worked really good. I could play the best games with high frame rate. The battery seems to have very long life. I was playing a lot so I can recharge it in the evening and the fast charge is ultra cool! Super fast charging is awesome and with my newly bought powerbank- I even get my fast charge from the powerbank! 
The preinstalled applications are cool. I use some of them and I find them cool. I use the 32GB version of the phone and so far I can't fill it all. I make the best picture quality and video, I have installed many applications and still the phone have a lot of space, plus you get OneDrive space for 2 years plus google space and you have a lot of cloud space. 
If you want even more space for your phone, I suggest you install Flickr application. This is Yahoo application, connected to Flickr website, used from photographers from all over the world. You will get free 1TB !!! space and you can upload and upload and upload pictures with the best quality! 
The sound is very clear during talk and loud enough so I can hear the person on loud places. 
The screen is super bright! During day, even direct sunligh on my scree, I can see everything super clearly! This is just awesome! 
Both cameras are cool and super quality. You get a lot of camera modes from the Samsung store application for free! They are pretty cool! 
There is Ultra saving mode for the battery and believe me, the phone can and will last for days, maybe even a week! The good thing is that if you don't use your phone during night, the % of the battery do not drop. It just stays there. 
You can dual screen and I found it pretty useful to check instagram and facebook at the same time or watch a video on youtube and browse the internet at the same time. 
After the update to Android 6.0.1 the phone seems stable. There are no problems and it is even better, when it comes to call people or they call you. 
The new Andorid is not so different, but my phone use less RAM and I have much more free RAM now. 
Overall, the phone will surve you well. It is elegant and with light weight. 
If you can get it- get it! You will like it! 
There are more positive things to say, but I just can't remember what else. Oh, well. Have a nice day!

Tips for better battery life: 
- Only use location when necessary 
- When you have a mobile data plan, switch of Wifi toggle when going outside 
- When at home and when you have Wifi, switch off toggle for mobile data 
- No push e-mail, but do it manually or set it on 1 hour or 3 hours 
- No weather widget (set a bookmark in your browser) 
- Try to keep your widgets at a minimum (I only have Google search widget) 
- No facebook app (set a bookmark in your browser) 
- Don't use battery saving apps (they eat from your battery as well) 
- Switch off notifications for as much of apps as possible 
- Keep your brightness on the lower side (indoor t's still usable at around 20% brightness) 
- Set it on flight mode while sleeping

Galaxy S6: 16 MP, f/1.9, 1.12 µm pixel size 
Galaxy S7: 12 MP, f/1.7, 1.4 µm pixel size
 
Megapíxels mean nothing to quality, just how big you can print a picture.  
On the other hand, the bigger the f and the pixel size, the more light gets inside the sensor(here the S7 has it bigger) this helps in 2 things: 
 1. You can capture things that otherwise would be completely black in your picture (thanks to that I don't need flash sometimes even in discos), a difference of f/0.2 here is quite big in phone cameras! 
 2. The shutter speed can be faster as more light will enter the sensor; this will make your pictures to not appear blur.
 
So as always with photography, we will need many pictures and compare each other to see which one is better!

I've gotten my samsung s6 for 2 months now.  
I love the multi-tasking function where I can minimise windows and use 2 apps at the same time. I love the camera, which produces really clear pictures, and has a huge zoom function. I like the new layout of Messages.
 
Unfortunately, my Samsung phone has restarted twice on me in the first 5 weeks, and in 2 months it suddenly stopped responding, despite me trying to call it or press buttons. Eventually it restarted.  
Also, this phone has a lag time when unlocking the phone, compared to HTC One, my previous phone. Sometimes, after closing apps, it can also take up to 5 seconds to load the home screen.  
Next, the fingerprint lock function doesnt work when your fingers are damp.  
Lastly, I'm no engineer, but the phone heats up a lot when fast charging. 
 
Other than that, its still a great phone overall, and its interface is great. Not sure how it would compare to other android phones on the market now.

I had an Honor 6 which worked wonderful until the battery died almost suddenly a couple of weeks ago, luckily though the phone is still under warranty but the local dealer is quite bad, it has been about 3 weeks since I send it to them and still it's not ready yet !! that and the fact that the battery life seems to be a common problem with many other honor 6s as I've read over the internet will make me depart from Huawei and might not buy from them again, so as a replacement I bought Galaxy S6 and here are my first impressions: 
1- the performance is almost the same as both phones have 8 cores and 3GB ram despite the different GPU but you wont notice much different, therefor, I was not impressed at all. 
2- I missed the SD card option on the Honor and don't think the added internal storage of the S6 would make for it. 
3- while I hope the battery of the S6 will live longer it certainly is way much limited in capacity and requires frequent charges through the day even though I don't play games nor watch much videos, with the Honor I was using it heavily and need to charge it only once per day. 
4- somehow the user interface of Honor is far much better and more convenient than the S6 which is a bit weird giving the size and market exposure of Samsung in the global market. 
5- lastly the camera of the S6 definitely has a noticeable advantage over the Honor but unfortunately I don't use it a lot so it's out of my interest. 
So all in all apart from the looks the the sleek design of the S6 I do not consider it an upgrade from Honor 6, contrary to that I'm a bit annoyed by the very low capacity of the battery and the extremely high consumption of the phone, I think I will have to replace it in the near future with another one.

So many people want to call out different handsets on specs, speed and OS.
 
Take it back to the basics - I have had both Android and iOS devices, I would also like to try a Windows phone at some point.
 
What do you ACTUALLY use your phone for?
 
- Calls 
- SMS 
- Internet 
- Music 
- Organisation 
- Games - maybe.
 
Why do people get 'die hard' over a brand of handset, when in fairness to all of them, they tick all of the above boxes.
 
Android and iOS are marketed to different types of customers, kind of like what BlackBerrys were in the 90's to businessmen/corporate types.
 
iOS - Simple, neat looking, no thrills, however they are tremendously popular due to that.
 
Android - (Can be) Complex, customisable, however they are tremendously popular due to that.
 
Fan boys on both sides need to get a grip... no one really uses their phone to their full potential anyway.

I've had my S6 for about a week now, and so far I'm happy enough, but I have no idea where the gushing praise of the device is coming from. The hardware does feel premium, but so did my M8, so does the iPhone 6, so do a dozen other devices. Putting it against the iPhone 6 specifically, I personally like the much more rounded feel of that device than the sharper feeling edges of the S6. That's very likely better for grip in the end, but it loses a lot of its "wow factor" for me based on that alone. 
 
The camera is very much praise worthy, however. I've been blown away by it's performance so far and can finally stop being an apologist in regards to virtually every other Android OEMs complacency here. We've been begging for a high quality camera for years and Samsung finally gave in and knocked it out of the park. Is it better than the iPhone 6 camera? Hard to say, but that's a good thing. How each camera deals with different things has become more a matter of personal preference than something obvious. 
 
Does it look like an iPhone? Yes and no. Looking at it from an angle at a slight distance and you may end up taking a second look just to confirm which it is. Head on, the oblong home button and shiny "Samsung" logo shouldn't confuse anyone. I think any similarities are more reflective the general homology across all devices. We've sort of converged on a general device style that unfortunately leaves little room for real innovation. Sure, there are some basic aesthetic tweaks that can be applied and evolved, but we're far away from anything truly revolutionary.
 
TouchWiz is interesting, but it's still just TouchWiz. It's the same ugly notification shade, it's the same collection of apps that for the most part don't really improve on it's stock AOSP or Play Store counterparts, and it's the same attempt at software differentiation as a brand strategy that I just can't imagine is working. I mean, I don't think people are buying Samsung phones for TouchWiz, but what do I know? That said, I don't exactly feel compelled to flash anything just yet (even if there were roms around). The device finally doesn't feel like its working against itself with regards to performance. Apps open when I want them to, the camera really does launch in under a second, and the stuttering that does happen feels more like it's a problem with the app than the phone. 
 
The battery life is still up in the air for me.

Got mine yesterday. 
 
It was between the S6 and the Nexux 5X(same price). Having got the 5X a few weeks ago i sent it back because the screen looked awful and the speaker/headphone volumes were pretty bad.
 
The screen on the S6 is amazing. Coming from the OP1 which was pretty good itself, this is another level. Speaker is good. Headphone volume good. It is a bit laggy here and there but once i decide if I'm definitely keeping it I'll stick on a bloatfree rom.
 
I prefer stock Android on the 5X and i like the placement and speed of the 5X fingerprint sensor better. I'd say i have an 80% first time success rate with the S6 sensor.
 
Only major issue is i have the Isocell camera sensor. But I'll only be taking photos for Facebook so it probably won't make a difference for me. If there was a huge drop off in quality between the 2 sensors more would have been made of it.
 
So at the moment I'm on the side of keeping it at least until the next round of Nexus phones.

The reason why I originally made the post below is to help others (apparently, not all) in their purchasing decisions especially since the smartphone is increasingly being used  to watch online videos, listen to music, play games, breaking news and social media updates, etc. (in addition to calls and text) which means a big 1080p screen, a  powerful 4000 mAh battery, a very good processor/GPU combo (SD 652, Adreno 510), and all the SD card space (128GB) when you need it, at HALF the price of flagship phones spells the difference between wall hugging, squinting, and buyer's remorse, to truly living and enjoying all that a smartphone has to offer in the smartphone era. 
---------- Original Post -------- 
The Samsung Galaxy A9 is a vastly better device than this one. 
1. Display - 1440x2560 (2.5k) is overkill unless you are into the dizzying VR hobby. 1080p is enough for this display. And no, you won't see better resolution with this display compared to a 1080p display. It only wastes battery and lowers device performance. 
2. 4000mAh should be the minimum battery standard nowadays. What's the point of a gorgeous display that is dead by lunch time if you use it fairly frequently to watch videos  
or play games or stream music? 
3. Dual sim should be the standard nowadays. One SIM for cheaper data package and another SIM for cheaper phone calls and text package --- or one sim for home and another for work or for local and international travel to save on roaming data. There are plenty other uses for two SIMs and the latest Android versions support them, so why limit one's flexibility? 
4. Why no SD card support? SD card support is very useful for people who love to have the entire music collection, HD movie collection and photo collection in their PC's, available anytime, anywhere in their phones even without data connection. They can mirror or screencast (wifi-direct) the movies and photos to any TV anywhere they go, no internet connection needed! The Samsung Galaxy A9 is a vastly better device than this one. 
1. Display - 4K is overkill unless you are into the dizzying VR hobby. 1080p is enough  
   for this display.  And no, you won't see better resolution with this display compared to  
   a 1080p display.  It only wastes battery and lowers device performance. 
2. 4000mAh should be the minimum battery standard nowadays. What's the point of a gorgeous display that is dead by lunch time if you use it fairly frequently to watch videos  
or play games or stream music? 
3. Dual sim should be the standard nowadays. One SIM for cheaper data package and another SIM for cheaper phone calls and text package --- or one sim for home and another for work or for local and international travel to save on roaming data. There are plenty other uses for two SIMs and the latest Android versions support them, so why limit one's flexibility? 
4. Why no SD card support? SD card support is very useful for people who love to have the entire music collection, HD movie collection and photo collection in their PC's, available anytime, anywhere in their phones even without data connection. They can mirror or screencast (wifi-direct) the movies and photos to any TV anywhere they go, no internet connection needed! Besides, smartphones nowadays offer ever increasing camera resolutions (18 MP+) and ever increasing video resolutions (4K) which will devour a standard 32 GB internal storage in no time.

I have had this phone for six months now, and it is without a doubt the worst smartphone purchase I have ever made.  Before the S6, I owned iPhones (3-5), which were fine products, but my wife purchased a Galaxy S5 and I really liked its performance and the ability to remove and replace the battery and memory to it.  I really had hoped that when I upgraded from iPhone 5 to a Galaxy S6 with my provider that it would be an improved product.  Well, that has not been the case.  The battery life is terrible.  I have uninstalled and disabled virtually everything I can (including the bloatware from the provider), outside of the bare minimum, factory reset the phone three times, burned through two S6s (after my first had this problem, to which my provider pretended never to have heard of this issue at all and gave me a new S6), and the battery drainage is never ending (I turn off all notifications and background data usage).  It just keeps draining.  Of course, come to find out, the fine people at Samsung decided to give us a smaller battery on the S6.  It shows.  That makes this a non-recommended product just for that.  I have to keep this phone on a charger at almost all times.  I have gone from 100% down to 10% back up to 100%, and then back down to 10% in a single day (depending on my access to a charger at work).  There is no excuse for this.  The battery alone makes it an inferior product.
 
Second, before the S6, what made Galaxy products so interesting, to me, was the fact they had (unlike iPhones) removable battery and SD memory card capabilities.  The S6 does not have those.  So, you receive a smaller, overheated, dying battery, which you need to constantly charge, but not way to replace it.  To say this is a trap would be putting it kindly.  Like a fool, when I bought this product, I assumed it would have the removable battery and SD card slot, like my wife's S5 (and every previous Galaxy product).  I cannot understate what a disappointment this is to me (next to its terrible battery life).  If you have a Galaxy S5, do yourself a favor and keep it.
 
The only attribute this phone has going for it, and it is its one nice feature, is the camera.  It is 16 megapixels, and it takes wonderful pictures.  So, if you like having a really good camera with no battery life, no memory or battery removal capabilities, have to minimize virtually all of your internet activities so they don't drain what little of your disappearing battery life you have left, and is just a worse version of the iPhone, well, the Galaxy S6 is for you.
 
In short, I will never purchase another Samsung phone ever again after this.  It is a fraud.  I have seriously considered just paying the remaining cost on the phone, blowing it up (so my provider does not recycle it and rip off another unsuspecting customer), deserting my provider altogether, and dishing out the money for a Nexus 5, but I will have to wait another year before that.  Until then, happy charging.

So I have been using Samsung Galaxy S6 (SM-G920FD) and here's my insight on it:
 
==》 Design & Handling: 
The design is somewhat industrial. It looks good and everything but it's just too common. Also, the back is a fingerprint magnet (visible even on my white device) and the frame tends to warm up (not scorching hot!!) when used intensively and could be a bit uncomfortable. Very slightly raised corners helps a great deal with handling too. 
7/10
 
==》 General Performance: 
The device is quite snappy and has a lot of raw power, however don't think you won't run into a couple of hiccups every once in a while. While they might be small, they are still noticeable. Also, watch out for RAM usage, Touchwiz uses a lot and autostarting applications can bog it down even more. 
6/10
 
==》 Screen and Audio: 
Screen is just so superb. It's supremely sharp and combining that with infinite contrast and maximum brightness, it remains perfectly legible even in the brightest of conditions. Viewing angels and colour rendition also strike home runs. Overall, it's the best screen I've seen on any device yet. 
Audio is not the loudest, but good enough. The output quality is amazing though, and 24-bit FLAC support is also appreciated. 
9.5/10
 
==》 Battery: 
All I'm going to say is that it's good enough. But I've seen better. 
6/10
 
==》 Camera: 
Superb sharpness, excellent dynamic range, great contrast and colour rendition. However, no native RAW support (third party applications needed, best result "Camera FV-5") and no manual shutter (max 0.5 seconds time limit using third party applications).  
9.5/10
 
Overall: 8/10
 
This must be noted that all this subjective to personal opinion, I myself is a power hungry user and while I'm writing this, my phone is at 14% and I've been using it with WiFi on for the last 6 hours, with on screen time 3.5 hours. It was at 94% at 8 o'clock in the morning.
One of the best mobile Phone i"ve ever used.. i use to dislike samsungs, but this one is simply the best.

Overall great phone, BUT.... 
Samsung's losing battle with RAM consumption: Coming from an S3 which was an incredible device, it had 2GB RAM, on average you would have about 850MB free. Now with the S6, 3GB available, yet somehow you still get about 900MB free. 
 
Call/Text issues: At times calls will go straight to voicemail with no indication that you have received/missed a call. This happens at random so you wouldn't know when to expect it. This issue somewhat applies to texting as well, although they will eventually come through....all at once.
 
Random irrelevant issues: not a lot of variety for the homescreen/lockscreen clocks, (personal preference) the phone could use a better "Black Theme" with more appealing icons, and finally on the clock icon - the second hand does not continuously update, seems like they tried to go for an iPhone style icon and failed.
 
Other than that, the hardware is excellent, it's quick, both cameras produce great quality pictures, the display is brilliant, its speakers produce a very rich and enhanced sound for both calls and media.

With this wonderful display and super duper fast processor that is a battery life to be satisfied with. You just have to know how to use an Android device, putting off Location and Google Now, Sync always swittched off, manual refesh mail not push mail, Wifi off when you go outside, otherwise your phone will keep searching for wifi everywhere you go and that drains battery too. When you're at home or somewhere where there is wifi, switch off mobile data so the 4G LTE signal will not be sent to your phone, waiting for you to use it :) Also never use Auto brightness. Switch off apps or even delete pre-loaded apps you don't use. Don't download battery saving apps cause the app itself is eating from your battery. Don't use much apps which run in the background. Facebook delete it and use the browser page of Facebook. I knew about the RAM and battery issues before I bought this phone, but like I said I know how to use my phone so here I am enjoying it and being happy with the battery life. Adios.

We spent a lot of time putting apps and customized settings on the phone before we switched from our old S4s to these phones. 
Hours of effort. Activated phones and within hours found you could not even mms someone while on a call, let alone get on the internet or tether to your laptop: we were shocked. Called my carrier, they told us the S6, Note 5, and the latest iphones have had this "voice over LTE" feature removed. 
Wow ! The elephant in the room no one is talking about. Why the big secret ? Google Search for S6 reviews: where do they talk about this ? Search S6 no data while on phone: almost nothing. 
I will guarantee you S6s sold in asia have not had this ability removed on LTE phones. 
We returned our phones for S5s. 
Pain for us, pain for our carrier to process returns. If we had been told this by telesales (when we asked about differences between the phones), we would not have choose the S6. 
Apparently they are giving Americans the candy functions instead of the antenna because we are too dumb to multitask in the information era. 
American consumers need to set them straight or no future phone will be able to use "voice over LTE". 
Shocked and will stay that way !

I have a very reliable memory card from 2008. It was first used in a Nokia E51 then E71 then E73 then a Galaxy S2 i9100 and it's presently in my Galaxy S5 G900h. So for all those who thinks memory cards are a thing of the past or should be a thing of the past you have no idea what you are saying. Nothing beats backing up your data to a memory card and computer...furthermore Internet connectivity isn't needed when using those methods but Internet connectivity is certainly needed when backing up to cloud storage. Regardless, cloud storage still has it's advantages. At the end of the day local storage such as memory card slot is important.

S6 is a brilliant phone. Phone of the best so far this year. If you don't own the phone, or barely got it, honestly, you shouldn't complain. If you don't have one, don't judge the book by it's cover and start assuming things because you saw the "Specs" and other people's opinions. And if you just got one, test it out for a few weeks to a few months. You'll never see the full beauty of the phone if you haven't seen most or all of the functions. There are always pros and cons to a smartphone. It's been like that since forever. But just cause of some slight negatives, don't bash out on the phone like it's some trash. I used almost all the samsung smartphones upto now except the s3 cause I used iphone 4s when it came out, but thereafter I was always samsung. Did Samsung copy apple in some ways? Yes. but Apple also has been copying some of the software aspects of samsung for years now. But what Samsung has done for their couple newest phones are quite impressive and is worth looking at. This can be a quick simple tip for those who are quick to judge at these tech gadgets. 1. When you buy a new smartphone, always buy it couple months after release. This goes for any phone. Sometimes, when you buy a new smartphone, there is a high chance that the phone can have a lot of problems. *The tests the company runs before release isn't always perfect*. Within the several months wait, the company finds issues and sends out updates for bug fixes and defects and all other problems. I bought my Galaxy S6 end of July, and have been using it since. It's always good to research the phone you want before you purchase, so you don't look stupid when you get the phone. and when i say research, I'm not just talking about looking at specs, but other things as well, such as good tips and tricks and apps that can make you look like iron man with your phone. Sure, some of the negatives of the  phone can get annoying, but there are solutions to those, and after a while of getting used too, it can be an effective phone. To those that are worried about battery life, you can either charge it to full, wait for it to be aroun 1 % and recharge it, or you can either by an portable battery charger so you can charge it on the go or when an s6 battery case comes out, you can purchase that.

I bought mine 7-2-2015 and love it.  I am a newby to smart phones.  Love it; it delivers all of what the hype says. Features I never expected and am still trying to use. Really like the wireless charging (which requires another $35.00 unit, but well worth it; just set it on and charge, no plugging and unplugging!).  If you are an Android person, I recommend this phone. I like the finger print ID-up to 4. If you are anal and need the instant messages, then maybe the S6 Edge is for you.  Anywho, check out the reviews and decide for yourself.  Just remember that Apple and Android are different operating systems with but with a lot of the same apps.  It seems there are several apps to sync iTunes to Android, so if you switch from iOS to Android, no big deal; they will still sell you their songs.   lol  Hope this helps some of you out there; just remember to research the phone you are interested in on the WEB; CNET, PCMAG, PC World, and so on. Look and decide what you want and don't forget to go to a dealer and see and feel what they are.  You are going to be the one holding it and using it; you have to love the feel, as well as the features.   { Note: if you have Android tablets; nexus 7/10 or such that have Micro USB charging ports, the S6 has the same; for charging or connecting with your desktop or laptop for easy file transfer, or recharging on the go if you already have chargers; I did, another convenience.  I guess I just don't like proprietary plugs that change with every iteration of models.

I switched to Galaxy S6 from Note 4 recently, here are my observations....
 
1. 40% faster processor (cpu and gpu) For the first time I saw no lag in Real Racing 3... 
 
2. Battery Timing - 10% max difference in battery life if compared with Note 4 ... it can be achieved by Greenify. Dont worry about battery life its perfectly ok. This mobile can survive whole day easily with moderate daily usage. It seems that S6's battery management is excellent (5.1.1 OS) 
 
3. Camera is 50% better than Note 4 ... Night photos are simply amazing.... OIS is much much better producing smooth shake free videos
 
4. Build quality is 100% better no question about it. 
 
5. Front camera is 100% better , 5 megapixels produces much better photos

Samsung's designers clearly have made a huge mistake in their design shift towards using non-replaceable batteries in the S6, S6 Edge, and the A and E series. Samsung has forgotten that many of their smartphone customers chose Samsung over the iPhone because they prefer the convenience and practicality of having user-replaceable batteries. Having a phone with a user-replaceable battery means that you will not be forced to leave your phone (for many weeks to even more than a month!) to a technician or service center just to have the battery replaced. With a user-replaceable battery, you just buy a new battery and thereby avoid being terribly inconvenienced (to say the least)of leaving your phone to a service center and not being able to use it for many weeks! Plus your privacy is compromised because the service center technician can view your files, photos, text messages, etc. And with a user-replaceable battery, you can just carry an extra battery along with you, so that when your phone's battery get drained you just replace it with your extra fully-charged spare battery. Changing the battery takes only a couple of minutes. Saves you the trouble of carrying a bulkier/heavier powerbank, because a spare battery is much smaller/slimmer and lighter in weight than a powerbank. Plus you don't have to suffer the inconvenience and difficulty of having a powerbank attached to your phone while you are on the move. So Samsung... wake up! Bring back the design of having phones with user-replaceable batteries, or you will surely be losing many customers who really want phones with user-replaceable batteries. Many Galaxy S5, S4, S3 users have already said that they will not buy the S6 nor the S6 Edge... and instead buy another phone brand that offers a user-replaceable battery design. I myself will never buy a phone with a non-user-replaceable battery.

you should know and everyone else too, the more you clean the surface of your screen, the sooner it will break. 
here is how it is 
corning glass is nothing but a glass but because of its manufacturing process, it has a hardness level of 7 on a scale of 1 - 10, so any material equal to 7 or above will scratch your display ( thats why dirt can scratch it ) 
now they also add a oleophobic layer to make make it fingerprint resistant and smudge resistant. this layer makes water/oil slip your display
 
now why his phone didnt break and mine did? 
the thing is this olephobic layer takes most of the hits and scratches on this layer can only be seen in UV light. 
once the layer gets totally removed from a particular part of display, glass on that area is totally exposed. this means beginning of tiny scratches era. 
the more the scratches on a display, the more the glass looses its integrity and if there are more scratches, your display might even break from 20 cm fall coz the reason is simple => glass is already shattered from various tiny places ( aka scratches ), that drop just became a catalyst to a bigger one.
 
thats why its a MUST to add a screen protector over your display or glass protector as it gets most damage and your displays integrity is maintained.

 
incase you always had a screen protector and it still broke from a fall, you are one unlucky guy.

Many people still don't understand how corning gorilla glass works. Newer gorilla glass doesn't always mean better. Gorilla glass 2 is more resistant to shock but not to scratches. Gorilla glass 4 is more scratches proof but it also make the glass more brittle than its predessessor. Higher resistant to scratches equal to loss of durability and more brittleness. Cornings put more tension on the glass so to make it scratch resistant but the tension build up made it weaker.
If you love a camera phone then this is the best. Camera and display is outstanding. Battery backup is little less but ok.

I strongly disagree on your updates parts. People were complaining not even 1 month earlier that all Galaxy S got updated to lollipop but not Note 4.
 
And concerning real flagship, i strongly disagree too. Designs and sizes are different, that's a sure thing. Rest is totally subjective.
 
My cousin just bought a Note 4 (he had a Note 3 while i said to him to wait for Note 5 but hey, it's his money). I have a S6 Edge.
 
S6 is faster in many tasks, UI is also smoother. Don't mistake me, performance is great on Note 4 but S6 is still above.  
Note 4 strongly looks like my Galaxy Alpha if anyone noticed in bigger format (due to its metal frame). 
Battery may be better, but in intensive/high usage it's still draining like any flagship : we installed lollipop update on it and phone lost about 20% battery during the process. 
At the end of the day, all depends of the user, he was constantly charging his phone when his Note 3 reached 50% range whereas i never charge my phones (being Alpha, S5 or S6 ) unless they turn off by themselves or i reach obviously too low state to go on for the rest of the day.  
Currently on vacation abroad, i have my alpha lasting like 3 days (usage = some photos/videos, a few calls received and 1 or 2hours of match 3 game per day). 
My S5 = charging every 1-1.5days because lots of calls, sms, rss, whatsapp, mails, photos and 4K videos shooting. 
My S6 = charging maybe every 3 days because almost no calls on it, a few photos, receiving a few texts and using it as a wifi hotspot for 1 or 2 hours a day.
 
Conclusion, battery being good or bad depends only of the usage made by the user, not only its size.

I had one Samsung S6 32G 6 weeks and I have to say that I'm very disappointed about the experience with this phone. 
First of all I have to say that I bought the phone from Romania - Orange network, from the second week of use it started to lose signal and the battery was draining very fast. One full charge lasted from 7.30-8 AM to 2-3 PM. 
I've sent the phone to the warranty, came after 3 days and they said that they "calibrate the signal and reinstall the software"... After one day the phone had the same problem (signal drop and fast battery drain) 
I've sent the phone again to warranty (Orange network) 
It came after 5 days and they said that they changed the charger, the back of the phone. But surprise the problem was still there. Crap phone, and crap warranty stuff. 
I had Samsung S2, S3, S4, S5... This phone is a shame, it looks fantastic well, the display is impresive but you cant use it like a phone. When the signal dropped it only came back after you restart the phone. All my friends told me that I have the phone closed, i've changed the sim card also, nothing changed... 
Switched on a Samsung Note 4 from one week now and the problem is solved :) the battery last until 22-23 PM in the night with a full charge at 7.30-8AM and no drop in signal. 
Think twice before you go for this phone...

I have been using the indian version of galaxy s6 black sapphire for a week now and so far it has been a great phone. 
Internal storage of 25gb in 32gb model. 
Screen looks gorgeous and Camera is superb. Even low light shots turn out to be great. 
It felt a bit slippery initially though due to back glass but I got used to it now. 
Overall it is a very fast device but occasionally slight stutter is there, but thats negligible. 
Charging is super fast, from 30 to 100% in about 50 min. 
Battery is neither too great nor too bad. I easily get 5 hrs sot with 20% brightness since I work indoors mostly. Standby is too good.I lose 2% overnight at most in power save mode. 
I consider myself a moderate user and usually I come back in evening with battery around 50 to 60%. 
I havent experienced overheating or battery drain problem so far. 
Overall I would say if you want android phone, s6 is the best.

I left Australia at the start of March in 2012 to travel the world indefinitely. I'm currently writing to you from Mendoza in Argentina and have been now traveling over 3 years. From the middle east Europe, down the east coast of Africa, back to Europe then Cuba, Jamaica and then Central America before South America and recently 11 days in Antartica.  Why am I telling you this? Because the whole time I've been traveling without a 'Proper' computer or  Camera  just  my phone to do  both functions and that phone is the same Galaxy S2 I'm writing  to you on now. So as much as I like specs and construction of the S6 as someone who has used his phone heavily daily in extreme climates and who values practicality over looks I have found a removable cardslot invaluable when my charging port failed and couldn't move my  photos via USB or via  the net because in a lot of these countries it's too slow or non existent. The same goes for the battery, I've changed mine several times and just before Antartica when my charging port  failed again (a weakness on the S2) I was able to use an external charger on what was one of the most expensive and memorable  trips (Antarctica) of my lifetime.  So for me a removable battery and SDcard slot are important and should not be overlooked when it comes to redundancy.
No removable battery, no radio, no SD Card slot means no money from me. I'm still using my Galaxy S2 which has all these features!

Yes, DLNA is particularly a software and works on DLNA compliant devices as Server (mostly PC, Smartphone, Tablet, NAS, MAC, etc.) and\or client (TV, music system, etc.).

Lagging usually occurs when a app or video stream is large which uses up a large amount of a phone's ram and cache.
 
A ram of at least 1gb will prevent lags, fps (frames per second) also go a long way in having smooth video streaming and gaming so try using stream quality and gaming quality matching or just below your screen's display pixels (480p, 720p or 1080p). Not much content out there for 4k and especially 2k so you'll be stuck watching stretch 1080p vids. 
 
Memory ram and Gpu is the main over 500mhz will help in lagless smooth gaming for gaming quality fitting your display. High gpu speed is the main reason why although iphones have 1gb ram and a dual core processor high end gaming is still excellent and some of the best on their phones.

Until now, all my smartphones have been HTC. I've always preferred the build quality and Sense. My previous phone was an HTC One. It's been a brilliant phone with little to pick fault with. It's only flaw has been the camera. It's OK but not great. So my next phone was going to be an HTC One (M9). However I had a chance to compare this with the S6 and there was really no competition. The build quality on the S6 is great. It's a bit slippery in the hand but apart from that it's fine. The other thing that put me off Samsung phones in the past has been TouchWiz. It has always looked like it had been designed by 'Fisher Price'. This is no longer the case. It's still not as polished as Sense but it's vastly improved and very liveable with. The M9 isn't a vast leap on from the M7. The S6 is. All the reviews and comparisons of the S6 are generally fair and accurate. Finally, as nice looking as the S6 Edge is, it isn't as nice as the S6. The screen edges reflects light too much and when it's on it's back it's difficult to pick up as the edges are too thin. These simple things made the Edge unusable for me.

So, I just received my S6 from T-Mobile pre-order. I had to go the T-mobile store to activate and even the worker there couldn't believe I got it so fast. This is my upgrade from Nokia N9 since Microsoft has closed all support to N9 I had no other choice. I still love N9 but the lack of support and apps finally got to me. 
 
So, back to the S6; I've had it for 4Hr now and so far no complaint besides the battery. I hope this is because As soon as I got it I went on a setup and app download spree. Charging was pretty fast(It came with 58% charge, and I was able to charge it to full within 25 minutes). Also, I noticed the phone was quite hot while it was charging.
 
The phone built quality feels very nice. It is one of the thinnest smart-phone I have physically come across as of yet. The design does have a drawback which is, it looks very much like an iPhone.
 
I went with the 32 GB option since I will only use it for normal phone things. I have a 128GB iPod if I need music and a Gaming PC and PS3/PS4 if I need to play game. Also, the phone comes with 115GB Skydrive Memory where I already have 1.025TB memory for buying Office 360, so now I have 1.125TB on the cloud.Therefor, memory is not a big deal breaker for me.
 
If I find any other drawbacks or advantage I'll definitely post it here first.

@aod, @1701. It is really ridiculous  to think apple copied Samsung Ativs  2012 design. Pioneering is about inventing a new idea or re-inventing an old , bad, unprofitable or bankrupt idea. Apple is very good in invention and re- invention. Apple has brought a lot of pioneering features to the mobile industry, recently are the voice command (Siri), 64 bit mobile operating system, finger print touch ID, Apple pay (mobile payment) , a very simply and user friendly interface and operating system. All of which Samsung and other major phones have followed in doing too. I know a lot of people will want to disagree on apples pioneering role in all the things above but you have to realize that if not for Apple most of the ideas above were not in existence or have been tried but failed by other companies in the past until Apple re- invented those ideas. Let's take the NFC, practically all major phones except Apple had it since 2yrs now but did nothing useful with it until Apple came up with the payment system and now Samsung has followed with their own Samsung pay pal , some people will now want to say but Samsung put in NFC first , the issue is what did they do with it before the Apple pay. Another feature is the finger print which was a bankrupt abandoned idea by Motorola and no other company was going in that direction until Apple re-invented the idea and turned it into millions of dollars and the result is most companies have followed it. Let now come back to the design issue. The ist iPhone is just a smaller version of the iPhone 6 in terms of the structural design , as in the rounded  edges. So it's ridiculous to say Apple copied Samsung Ativs 2012 design when it was used in the first iPhone back in 2007.  But let us even assume Apple copied the Samsung Ativs 2012 design, don't you wonder why Samsung had to wait for Apple to use that same design before they used it again in their premium phone. It was a design that was not continued after 2012 meaning it was a poor design to Samsung and was never included in any of their premium phones not until Apple turned that same design by your own assertion into millions of dollars in iPhone 6 and all of a sudden Samsung just realized its 3yr old abandoned design is a winner. I don't have a problem with phones copying one or two features from another. Apple borrowed the antenna lines from HTC M8, but if you place both the iPhone 6 and HTC M8 side by side you won't think they are same bcos they are different in their overall design. So I don't have a problem with Samsung copying Apple, but the problem which I have with the GS6 and which a lot of people and reviewers have with it is that it looks exactly like the iPhone 6, as in an exact copy of iPhone 6 save for the shape of the finger print scanner. Is it a coincidence that Samsung had to wait for Apple to introduce the rounded edges , antenna lines , one touch finger print (as opposed to Samsungs swipe in GS5 and note 4) in the same phone before they do it too. Have you even looked at the base of the GS6, the position of the headphone jack, the charging or docking port and the speakers, they are exactly where Apple put them in the iPhone 6. I still maintain my assertion that the GS6 is just an iPhone 6 with a Samsung logo on it with better specifications which might not mean better performance on the long run. I still maintain my assertion too that it's a very very good phone in design and specifications and will definitely give the iPhone 6 a run for the crown. 6 reasons not to buy Samsung Galaxy S6 
1. Same Look Makes People Unhappy
 
Galaxy S6 smartphone is not up to the mark and its design is same with a little brush up changes in the color contrast. So ultimately, its earlier edition of Galaxy S5 has the same look with little variance in design. So customers are not interested to lay their hands on this latest handset in spite of glossy appearance.
 
2. S6 with Low Energy Efficiency
 
Whether Galaxy S6 smart phone is cost effective and energy efficient depends on the battery life. There are many negative points to mention. However, the severe drawback is its less powerful battery compared to Galaxy S5 model.
 
3. Galaxy S6 Not Up to the Mark
 
When this Galaxy S6 handset was designed and then reset at the companys workstation, people came to know about the exact shape of this handset in advance. So, before being launched to the market, customers got information about the look, color contrast and design of this smart phone. So charm has been spoiled to have a look at this handset on the internet. It reduces the popularity of this smart phone to some extent.
 
4. Low Color Pixels/Resolution  A Drawback
 
Critics have highlighted low color resolution which is not modified. 2560 x 1440 pixel QHD resolution is not upgraded. So customers are not pleased to use this handset. However, picture displaying is better with a higher data storage space. Smartly speaking, youngsters want more gorgeous pictures to display. 557 Pixels every inch on the touch screen are not sufficient to produce the natural effect on the visual presentation of digital snapshots.
 
5. Low Energy Efficiency Level
 
Customers who are economical search for powerful smart phones with higher energy efficiency level. They dont want to spend money to replace batteries frequently. They want faster service without spending huge amount of energy/fuel. Truly speaking, this new edition is not capable of providing longer backup during emergency. That means, the battery life expectancy is not satisfactory.  The available strength of the micro battery is 2550mAh only. At first, customers expected that there would be good news about the replacement of the old batteries. However, at least they didnt get expected result as this smart phone has lack of strength to save the energy of the battery.
 
It is the major drawback. However, in a news release, the management of the company has claimed that it is not a severe breakdown. With the help of powerful recharger, one can power the battery soon within the span of 10 minutes. Consumers are confused whether they will have to wait for another superb handset in the upcoming monsoon. The stereotyped look has discouraged young sweethearts who are desirous of getting some innovative cell phones with wonderful decoration.  They dont negotiate with the style and color contrast of the smart phones. Perhaps Galaxy S6 will not energize them to go to the departmental stores to buy this handset on the spot.
 
6. No Micro SD Card Slot Available in Galaxy S6
 
Small but visible defects have also been surfaced by experienced mobile users. According to them, Micro SD card slots are unavailable in this handset. So it is a minus point to let customers to have a faster switchover to opt for the best handset. It is a prominent reason of the reduction of energy level of people to purchase Galaxy S6 model. The dashing and dynamic look of Galaxy S5 is still impressive to lure next generation. They dont want to compromise when they shop online to have sophisticated flip top smart phones at the reasonable prices.
 
So, you need to decide faster whether you are comfortable to handle this smart phone. Well, many believe that this Galaxy S6 is not water resistant. My Goodness! It is a fault on the part of the company. This handset will be damaged when it is drenched in water droplets. The interior decoration will be smashed and discolored.  So hurry up to have a new smart phone which is water proof with good resilience.  You must be a good buyer and therefore it is your job to find the best handset.
 
Last but not the least, if you are not experienced, come on to hit the internet to go through some current product reviews before planning to bring home this sleek smart phone.

With the Note 3, I saw benchmarks of nearly 70MB/sec from internal storage over USB 3.0 (not MTP), while MTP or USB 2.0 would yield more like 25MB/sec.
 
Meanwhile, a USB 3.0 card reader, which are cheap these days, can get 90MB/sec+ out of modern microSD cards like the Samsung Pro ($1 per gig) according to Tom's, and you know Tom's is right:  
 
Now I wonder what the Samsung Pro card would get in the S5 via USB 3.0 connected to a PC. This guy used a Sandisk Extreme card with his Note 3 and gets like 15 - 20MB/sec, not the best test though since it's not an S5 nor a Samsung Pro card:     I'm guessing the S5 is a tad slower than the dedicated card reader. Or does the S5 use MTP or USB2.0 for the microSD card and USB3.0 is only good for internal storage? I don't know and I guess I don't care either, haha.

Haha, waste or not, I don't care.
 
I treated my microSD cards like you do, leaving them in the device all the time. They were simply there to expand internal storage because Samsung only offers up to 32GB devices in America (why? we can't afford 64GB, Samsung? Aren't we the richest bastards in the world?). We'd better get the 128GB device on our carriers here if they want to directly compare to the iPhone6, which is obviously Samsung's goal.
 
Yeah there are tons of alternatives to SD cards, each with their own strength or weakness. While at home, use wifi and network file sharing. You can easily stream 1440p video on a decent 802.11n network. I use simple Windows file sharing accessed on Android with ES File Explorer. It works great. While away from home, if you really need more room, OTG is cheap while wifi-drives are convenient. With OTG, you're not limited by the measly 128GB max microSD card. I used my 2TB compact external HDD with NTFS file system even (had to use an NTFS mounting app on Android). With wifi drives, the 128GB models are seriously about the same price as a 128GB microSD card, yet you can use it with basically any wifi device instead of being limited to the dwindling number of devices with microSD slots.

Sounds you like would like the Galaxy S5 or LG G3. They are pretty cheap these days and have microSD. You could use a Galaxy S6 with OTG-adapter and a microUSB card reader with a 128GB card in it, but you don't want extra hardware to pack around. However, you said you backup photos to USB, so you must be packing around a laptop or something. You can still do that with the S6. Sounds like the only reason you starting using the memory card for files was because your microUSB port broke on your S2. Even if Andrdoid somehow broke on your new S6 and it wouldn't boot up, or perhaps you broke the screen and it doesn't recognize touches, your photos would still be on the data partition that won't get wiped when you factory reset your S6. If your pics are really that important to where you're THAT paranoid, maybe you should be using a D-SLR. Plus, backing them up or simply storing them directly on microSD card is not that good of an idea since microSD is fairly unreliable and you could lose all the data on it, not to mention it's slow and someone could steal it out of your phone and get your pics if you don't encrypt it. It would be a lot more likely to lose data from a microSD than from the /sdcard/ partition on internal storage.
 
I've said it before and I'll say it again: We have tons of phones with sealed batteries. Phone makers include a way to hard-reset phones without removing the battery. Even phones with removable batteries can be hard reset without removing the battery, usually by holding power for 5 or 8 seconds, sometimes in combination with volume-down or up. The fact that so many people pull their battery when their phone acts up is astounding to me. Maybe it's a behavior left-over from Blackberry users, but it's an out-dated belief, that's for sure.
 
Not trying to talk you into getting an S6, but I think people aren't really thinking about alternatives to having microSD + removable battery. They would rather whine about it which does zero good. Like Samsung gives a rip. The only thing that will make them listen is sales figures. If the S6 flops, they might consider adding microSD if possible with UFS 2.0 (still unsure if it's technically possible, but I'm pretty sure it is).

Any pixel density over 300ppi, therefore, is only going to benefit a small minority of people with exceptionally good vision, or those who have their phones glued to their noses. All of these extra pixels are going to go largely unnoticed, and do very little other than waste battery life  something which is frustratingly poor in all smart phones.
 
I dont mean this to discredit the amazing advances in technology, but now that most high end device manufacturers have reached the happy 300ppi, I would much rather they held back with this sort of thing and invested some time in better battery technology rather than wasting voltage on invisible pixels. Until we are walking around with smart phones strapped to our faces (Project Glass), I just cant see[!] how these additional pixels are going to improve my over all user experience.
