As far as some of those cons being pros for others (my opinion):
 
No memory slot - Good! The less slots the better, especially if it makes them ditch the 16GB model in favor of larger capacity. Plus, it helped them implement the super-fast UFS2.0 storage. Plus, Android sucks at implementing microSD cards (must have root and use tools to actually move apps to it).
 
Expensive 64 and 128 GB models - Hopefully the price gaps will be similar to how they were with 16/32/64. Maybe this means the USA will actually see a 64GB model (have we ever had a 64GB Galaxy device?). Maybe we will even get the 128GB model. While it is more expensive than microSD cards, it is a LOT faster, more reliable, and actually works with Android properly.
 
NoT waterproof - I don't care. They wasted weight, effort, time, cost, etc. on making it water-proof. A normal phone is water-proof enough for me.
 
Non-removable, smaller battery - Good! It's slimmer, lighter, more durable, unibody, etc. Batteries last longer than phones in my life (1.5 years between phones, approx.)
 
Headphone jack at the bottom - Fine by me, same as my last 2 phones. Works well cuz I put my phone in my pocket top-side first.
 
No (FM) radio - I don't care. I live in an area without any good FM stations. I subscribe to Pandora and SiriusXM. FM radio would be a wasted feature.
 
USB 3.0 to 2.0 change - Saves space and weight. The USB 3.0 speed would be nice from time to time, especially with the new UFS 2.0 storage, but the USB 2.0 standard works well enough for me since I rarely use it to transfer data. Plus, all the USB 2.0 docks and accessories will work with it.
 
I could keep going with other peoples' cons, but I won't.

Oh look, a spec battle!
 
But really, yes the iPhone specs are lacking on paper in some areas but they make up for it with their execution and overall package. That 1GB of RAM works pretty well still on iOS 8. That dual-core A8 CPU does well since more cores and higher max frequency doesn't always equate to better performance, like how the A8 trounces the SnapDragon 801 in many areas with half the cores and half the RAM and a lot lower max frequency (SnapDragon chips throttle quickly, so their 2.XGHz ratings are mostly just for advertising). The iPhone cameras do lack in detail, though, due to their lower resolution sensors. We need 16MP+ in our phones since like 2013. What happens when Grandma wants to crop her 8mp photo down to like 3mp, then she's looking at it in 10 years on her 8K TV and is like "why is my picture so small? And if I make it bigger, it looks grainy as heck. I thought the iPhone was a good camera!".
 
Meanwhile, many other phones have great specs but poor execution (TouchWiz homescreen lag still on GS6, Xperia's camera software failing to get good pics with best lens, Droid Turbo camera software as well, SnapDragon 810 overheating if that's true, Samsung's octa-core getting out-performed by dual-core Apple SoC's and SnapDragon 800 quad-core, Droid + Verizon loading up the phones with bloatware and locked bootloaders, etc.).
 
While I am not a fan of Apple as a company, you have to respect their execution. It really makes pretty much every other company appear sloppy and 2nd-rate. They have a tough image to keep up, that's for sure.

The headphone jack placement is bad or good depending on how you use your phone. If you use it in an armband holder or belt clip, or keep it upright in your pocket, then top is often better. If you keep it top down in your pocket or use an aux cable in your car, then then the bottom location is a little better. It all depends on the user habits ;)

A lot of people, me included, put their phone upside-down in their pockets because that way, when you grab it, it sits upright in your hand. In fact, it's the most natural way to put your phone in your pocket. With the jack on the underneath, you can listen to music without having to put your phone in your pocket in a dodgy way.

For what concern both competing companies, here is the real information:
 
 "Samsung Electronics, the worlds largest smartphone maker, grew sales by 17% in 2013 to nearly $209 billion  a record for the South Korean company. Samsung brought in over $27 billion in profit last year, but recently it has struggled as its Galaxy devices have come under pressure from Apples iPhone and cheaper Chinese device-makers. CEO Oh-Hyun Kwon hopes to continue the record-high revenues by expanding Samsungs medical and health, business-to-business and smart home units."
 
"Apple, the maker of the globally popular iPhone and iPad devices, posted sales of almost $171 billion in 2013, 9% higher than the prior year. But the company has come under pressure in the competitive smartphone business, and its profit shrank 11% to $37 billion from 2012 to 2013. Even so, Apple has a huge amount of cash on hand, and CEO Tim Cook recently deployed some of that cash pile by announcing $30 billion in stock buybacks."
 
So for your concern about financial performance of Samsung sales linked with there smartphones, you should see that it's not as bad as Apple. But you didn't mentioned Apple sales performances, because then you would have no more points to defend.

So not only I wouldn't be scared for Samsung if I was you, but I wouldn't worry for Apple as well, as both are registering huge profits year after year and they both have very highly skilled Head executives.

In the instruction manual for the Galaxy S6, Samsung offers instructions for removing the devices battery but warns that this should only be attempted by your service provider or an authorized repair agent. If you try to remove the battery yourself and you severely damage your phone, it will not be covered by your warranty.
 
So if youre willing to take that risk, here are Samsungs instructions for how you remove the battery:
 
Remove the SIM card tray from the device before starting battery removal 
Remove the back cover 
Loosen and remove the screws that line the perimeter of the device 
Remove the circuit board 
Disconnect the battery connector 
Remove the battery

I am not a Samsung fan. In fact, I vowed to never get another after I saw how they really hate rooting and unlocking of bootloader. I'd rather get an Apple device, and in fact sold my Note 10.1 2014 for an Air 2 because there just wasn't any Android tablet that was even 75% as good as the Air 2 (including the 10.5" Galaxy Tab S with the same laggy Exynos and UI as my Note 10.1). The new Sony Z4 tablet  would be my choice probably if I hadn't gotten the Air 2. I had also vowed to never get another Apple device after I got the iPad 4 and tried using it without jailbreak for a couple months (it took them awhile to jailbreak it), but the Air 2 was just too sexy, especially gold 64GB for $499 after selling my Note 10.1 for $370.
 
Yet despite my hatred for Apple and Samsung as companies due to their business practices, I can't help but appreciate fine craftsmanship like the Air 2 and this Galaxy S6. I wanted the M9 to make my decision easier, but the S6 is checking more boxes than the M9. I want to wait for the Z4 and G4 to see if they're going to best the S6, but it's going to be a tough wait.
 
The 2600mah battery in the S6 Edge will provide similar battery life to the S5 and your 6plus, I guarantee it. I think it will be just slightly worse than both, but I think it will be close enough to where you can go 48 hours of normal usage between charges if you need to. Heck, I was fine with my Galaxy Nexus and its TERRIBLE battery life because I use docks at work and home, so anything better than 24 hours of normal use is icing on my cake.

$700, ouch. Oh ya there was a high-performance mode on that one, wasn't there? I put a custom rom on it (CleanROM I think?) that had the full speed enabled by default all the time, so I didn't ever use anything less. Kind of like how I turn off TurboBoost on my Intel CPU so it hits the full 4.6GHz whenever it's busy instead of 2.8GHz or whatever. My TF700 was probably getting hot and thermal-throttling, but I didn't even notice because of other issues bugging me more.
 
I had the 32GB version with 32GB microSD and 64GB full SD in the dock. Was nice having that much storage for music, emulator roms, and videos, but ASUS just couldn't ever quite get it right with their high-end Transformers.

I'm pretty sure there will be an exploit discovered, but it's disappointing the see how Samsung's stance on bootloader-unlocking has gotten even worse than Apple's. At least with Apple, you can un-jailbreak and Apple never knows it was jailbroken, but with Knox you trip the bit and they can tell the bootloader was unlocked even if you relock it. At least in theory...with my Galaxy S4, I returned it to the stock rom and Knox went back to untripped. It's just dumb that it voids your warranty. What if Dell voided your warranty because you enabled the local administrator account in Windows after buying the PC? Or what if they locked the BIOS and voided your warranty if you wanted to change settings? I sold an ASUS TF700 tablet shortly after buying it. Since I unlocked the bootloader, ASUS voided my warranty. The next owner of the tablet had the digitizer break on them somehow, so they got stuck with a $270 repair bill for the $450 tablet.

Don't you hate the big fail that devs like Gameloft do with their file system?
 
There is a solution, though I haven't tried it since Jellybean on my Note 10.1 (2014) about 8 months ago. It's called FolderMount (there is another one too but FolderMount was better than the rest when I was using it). You basically choose what folder you want to spoof (dynamic link?) and it mounts a folder on your SDcard. So I set up the OBB folder and basically all the data that the standard "move to SD card" fails to do is in OBB so it is located on the SD card. It didn't hurt load time that much, though I did have a 35mb/sec mem card, which is decently fast. After that, I had like 8 Gameloft games installed that occupied over 10GB in my redicted OBB folder, and other companies' games as well taking up another 10GB+. I think there is another folder that is helpful to redirect, too, like the amazon appstore cache and google music cache or something like that, oh ya and my downloads folder since I would download roms and large files at times. It was mainly all about that OBB folder though. Stupid app devs...don't they know there are tons of poor souls with 16GB device that only have 9GB free with zero apps installed other than the stock ones?

Yeah, people that want to protect from losing data from a crash can do it easily without a mem card if they want. Like me for instance. I have a free 56GB drop box that pictures, videos, and any app-changes (app updates or app data like local save games) gets sync'd to via Titanium once a week in the middle of the night if the phone is charging at the time. It also covers personal data like SMS/MMS/Call Log and other items that Android doesn't sync with your gmail account automatically. Usually the scheduled backup doesn't have to upload much, but I can restore any app or game or whatever data I want from various points in time if needed, and of course pics and videos are sync'd to not only DropBox but also Google Photos and Wastebook (Facebook). You could do it with the basic 5GB free DropBox too if you don't take too many videos and pictures.

It is very possible to see a difference provided your eyes work as they normally should, go look at one and see. The text is sharper, images are more crisp, etc. It's just not a huge difference. And the screen's an AMOLED, they lose 0 battery life to QHD. That's only an issue with IPS screens as they have to use a backlight to illuminate the screen that loses brightness when the pixels are closer together (higher PPI). Think of it like a light shining through a screen. The tighter the weave on the screen, the less light that makes it through. AMOLEDs don't have a backlight at all, the pixels provide the illumination themselves, and are actually much MORE power efficient than an IPS screen. Do some research before spreading disinformation please!

There are a lot of comments pointing out that s6 copied the fruit device, small battery and no expandable storage, and this means "total and utter failure." Here's some points in favour of the s6
 
1. For those who have seen the mwc event, a direct comparison was made with photo and video of s6 and the fruit product. For the information of fruit users happy to be using 8mp for multiple generations(read : forever) that should be an eye opener. 
 
2. The s6 edge looks great in the hands on pics and vids at mwc, and which device was the edge copied from ?? If your response is the design is meaningless then please withold from such response till there is detailed review or usage of the final product by the people.
 
3. Complaints about battery life cannot be made without actual usage statistics. The mAh figure is just representative of the battery capacity and not of how efficient the device is or how well optimized. The G3 and the Note4 are fine examples on the bottom and top of the battery usage characteristics.
 
4. About the removable storage... 
a. the mwc event revealed usage of the new flash storage which will be a big upgrade in r/w speeds. 
b. Lets say you want to record a 4k video, what will be the processing times of a class 4 or even class 10 micro sd compared to the flash storage 
c. until the price points of the storage options are released it cannot be said whether sammy follows the path of cupertino in charging a huge premium for every increment in storage.

For those complaining about screen size and camera - get a life - the iPhone6+ is massive - too big for a phone, and if you have any idea about cameras, you should know that MP is only a fraction of the equation.
 
I personally don't like the "edge" phone at all, it looks stupid and I don't think that it's any real benefit. 
Wireless charging is cool, but how "wireless" is it? - You'll still have to sit the phone on the charging mat. You're still stuck with the phone on a table somewhere near a power point. Can you actually still use it in your hands whilst it's wirelessly charging? - I don't think so... All it will save people is a whole second of picking up cord and plugging it in! 
It would have been better if they put a kinetic charger in there that prolonged battery life as you used the phone during the day!
 
The "octo-core" processor is a good choice. 
People seem to care about improvements to the screen - so tick there. 
The metal/glass case will be a winner as Samsung were often critised for this - However at the cost of a removable battery?
 
Overall, I think for some (most) people, this will be a better phone for them then the GS5. For others, probably not. 
All those people saying they'll got to Apple because they don't like that this phone is more like an iPhone now - they're full of it, or complete morons.
I'm pity to those who keep complaining & whining about battery capacity without looking the efficiency of SoC and electronic components.

Simple, if they don't put LTE, half people will say it's old tech. 
If it doesn't support 2K resolution, people will say LG (and others are offering it).
 
If they cannot put more than 2600mA battery, it's because the phone will be very slim. If it's not slim enough, people will say it's too thick compared to new phones and start b!tching again.
 
Also, they cannot put more than 2600mA because they need to control the weight since if it has metal, it'll be already heavier than a polycarbonate based phone (previous Galaxy S).
 
And also, if they don't put bigger battery, they also may be thinking to people's safety : 
 With all those batteries exploding nowadays, maybe it's wiser to stay at not too high levels, especially for top seller phone (the more they sell, the more backfire they can potentially get if some batteries are defective). 
And to finish, to keep the costs down, for both the retail phone and separated battery.
